description: This page includes all models for the Temp_C_mean_daily variable.
title: Temp_C_mean_daily

table:columns.name: reference_datetime
table:columns.description: datetime that the forecast was initiated (horizon = 0)

table:columns.name: site_id
table:columns.description: For forecasts that are not on a spatial grid, use of a site dimension that maps to a more detailed geometry (points, polygons, etc.) is allowable. In general this would be documented in the external metadata (e.g., alook-up table that provides lon and lat); however in netCDF this could be handled by the CF Discrete Sampling Geometry data model.

table:columns.name: family
table:columns.description: For ensembles: “ensemble.” Default value if unspecified For probability distributions: Name of the statistical distribution associated with the reported statistics. The “sample” distribution is synonymous with “ensemble.” For summary statistics: “summary.”If this dimension does not vary, it is permissible to specify family as a variable attribute if the file format being used supports this (e.g.,netCDF).

table:columns.name: depth_m
table:columns.description: depth (meters) in water column of prediction

table:columns.name: duration
table:columns.description: temporal duration of forecast (hourly = PT1H, daily = P1D, etc.); follows ISO 8601 duration convention

table:columns.name: date
table:columns.description: ISO 8601 (ISO 2019) date of the predicted value; follows CF convention http://cfconventions.org/cf-conventions/cf-conventions.html#time-coordinate. This variable was called time before v0.5of the EFI convention. For time-integrated variables (e.g., cumulative net primary productivity), one should specify the start_datetime and end_datetime as two variables, instead of the single datetime. If this is not provided the datetime is assumed to be the MIDPOINT of the integration period.

data.title: Database Access
data.description:
Use `arrow` for remote access to the database. This R code will return results for the NEON Ecological Forecasting Aquatics theme.

### R

```{r}
# Use code below

all_results <- arrow::open_dataset(s3://anonymous@bio230121-bucket01/vera4cast/forecasts/parquet/project_id=vera4cast/duration=P1D/variable=Temp_C_mean?endpoint_override=renc.osn.xsede.org)
df <- all_results |> dplyr::collect()

```
       

You can use dplyr operations before calling `dplyr::collect()` to `summarise`, `select` columns, and/or `filter` rows prior to pulling the data into a local `data.frame`. Reducing the data that is pulled locally will speed up the data download speed and reduce your memory usage.
